title: What will the settlement price of the January 2017 Dubai/Oman Crude Oil futures contract be on 30 November 2016?
preds: January WTI Futures trading a bit below $50 after news of the OPEC agreement.  WTI trades at a dollar or two premium over DME, so it's looking like DME will close a couple dollars short of $50.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-oil-idUSKBN13O06N
Article reports OPEC has suspended Indonesia, and that its reported 700,000 bpd in October will be reallocated to other OPEC countries.   If Indonesia continues production outside of OPEC, the reports of OPEC production cuts seem somewhat overrated:
"A new wild-card was the suspension of Indonesia from OPEC Tuesday, sources said. The organization has agreed to distribute Indonesia's oil output share among certain OPEC countries. Indonesia produced about 730,000 barrels per day in October, according to an OPEC survey from Reuters."

The OQD marker price for the 29th November was $45.31 and the settlement price for January 2017 on the 28th November was $46.03. (dubaimerc.com)
I think it is very unlikely that the settlement price for the January 2017 futures contract will reach the $50 mark. After the meeting in Algiers back in September, Brent crude and WTI oil prices gained nearly 6% in one day - if there was a repeat tomorrow, it would not be enough to take the settlement price past $50. I also think it’s unlikely, though not impossible, that the settlement price will fall below $40. 
There are conflicting media reports about where OPEC and non-OPEC countries stand on the agreement, e.g. Russia is willing to continue dialogue with OPEC, but it is not willing to cut production - only freeze it at its current levels of over 11 mb/d, reports saying Iran will only agree to freeze and insist Saudi Arabia cut production by more than 1mb/d. It is clear that a deal must be made to rebalance the market, but given the current political situation (e.g. possible impact Trump could have on Iran with sanctions) - some countries will be looking to focus on what is more beneficial to them rather than as a global market. 
The important thing to remember is the DME Oman Crude oil futures contract trading closes 1630 Singapore time (0930 in Austria). We won’t know the outcome of the OPEC meeting until tomorrow afternoon, so it will be speculation by analysts, media and any comments made by ministers going into the meeting, as to whether they are optimistic or pessimistic about an agreement, tomorrow morning that will influence the settlement price.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
This assuming there is no war involving Iran, the Gulf States and or Israel

OPEC looks to have agreed on production cuts and has seemingly even gotten Iran and Russia onboard, with the former promised a cap instead of a cut. Whether this has already been priced in in the jump on 21 Nov remains to be seen, but it is possible investors are waiting for the meeting in Vienna on Nov 30 and any official announcements made there. The price will go up, but with just a week to go, it will be very close whether it will break $50.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

43.82 on 17 Nov, 2016. Iran, Iraq both are negotiating for a production freeze rather than a cut.  Market may have upside if a significant production cut at 32.5 mbd is agreed at the Nov. 30 OPEC meeting. Russia  (non-OPEC) is non-committed, yet may participate if a deal is made. OTOH: DTrump will be pro-US energy production.  Regulations may be reduced and greater US production seems likely as costs decline.  FED now favors a rate increase in December, likely lifting the price of oil (priced in $'s).  Current high levels of supply in the US may also hold the price down.

Readjustment on a previous forecast: 
Oil prices increased today (US light crude increased 5.8% and North Sea Brent crude was up 5.6%) based on the general view that OPEC will come to an agreement at the end of the month due to increasing pressure from oil companies to reign in the global glut and after news that a major Nigerian pipeline had been attacked. 
After the announcement in September that OPEC would agree to a production cut, DME Oman crude price increased 17% within 2 weeks. The OQD Marker Price for November 15th (listed on the DME website) is $42.79. So, if OPEC did come to an agreement and the oil price followed the same trend as last time, it would just breach the $50 mark - but that wouldn't be instantaneous.
However, if OPEC doesn't come to an agreement its possible oil prices could fall below $40
The OPEC meeting on 30 November is unlikely to succeed. Although markets will already have priced this in partially, Bayesian updating may still push prices down further still.

Prices have been more or less in a trading range between $40-$50 for the last several months, and in a short term downtrend the last two weeks. On the demand side, the long term upward trend due to world economic growth is still certainly in tact, but I think uncertainty around the US election may be having some effect.  It is possible that there will be a rally in price after the election, but I think a really big move is unlikely. On the supply side I think that increased production from Iran has been helping to keep a ceiling on prices.  US oil production has also leveled off over the last few months after falling since the middle of 2015.  There have been reports of a Saudi threat to increase production over disagreements between them and Iran.  My guess is that this really is mainly just a threat, but an announcement from Saudi Arabia of increased production could provide significant downward pressure on prices. My base scenario is a return to the intermediate sideways-upward trend in prices.  There is enough time still for a short term trend in prices to break out of the $40-$50 range by the end of November.

There are many factors that are weighing in on the price of Oman crude oil, but I think the main factors to focus on are: Exports to Asia make up a large quantity of Oman’s total exports, so the performance of those economies, mainly China, are vital in maintaining a stable price of Oman’s crude oil. 
           News article (source: platts.com) stated that China’s imports of crude oil would continue to grow in coming years to maintain higher levels of crude stocks for energy security. DME Oman publication also reported increased activity at ‘teapot’ refineries which also adds to the demand
           Oil markets supported by fuel for heating in the winter (OPEC MOMR October 16) - Worth keeping an eye on long-term weather forecasts throughout November to get a general idea of how much temperatures will drop in the coming winter.  According to OPEC MOMR October’16 issue Oman production will increase by 20tb/d. There are also a number of oil fields starting/resuming production in the 4Q and at the start of next year namely; Russia; Vostochno-Messoyakhskoye field, Launch of Suzunskoye field (which was supposedly in October) and Filanovsky filed in the Caspian sea (also supposed to be in October), Kashagan Field - Kazakhstan and Goliat - Norway.
         There were also media reports indicating that Yemen resumed oil production in August of this year - since the civil war began more than 18 months ago. 
         Non-OPEC oil supply is also expected to rise due to oil sands production (which was shut down due to wildfires in Alberta), continued rise in US oil rig counts and end of seasonal maintenance.            OPEC had stated in a meeting in Algiers (28th September 2016) that they would plan to freeze oil production in order to rebalance the market - an article from DME (dated 12 October 2016) said since this agreement was made, and comments from Vladimir Putin agreeing to such a deal, caused DME Oman crude to increase 17% since late September. 
          The OPEC meeting on November 30th is where the deal will officially be agreed. However, many analysts say OPEC won’t make a deal in November (Capitol Crude: “Post-Algiers Prospects: what’s really at stake when OPEC meets again in November” Podcast). A news article on CNBC stated that OPEC has been producing at record highs, making investors skeptical of its target at cutting productions
         According to CNN Money, Russia, Saudi Arabia and the United States are the worlds top oil producers of 2016. However, neither Russia nor the US are members of OPEC. Putin has agreed that Russia would partake in a deal to cut production - but with 3 new projects coming online in Russia, it doesn’t seem likely that they will uphold an agreement to such a deal.  OPEC crude oil production increased in September with the main output increases coming from Iraq, Nigeria and Libya. Worth noting that Libya and Nigeria are expected to receive special conditions from the OPEC deal, along with Iran. 
         News article (platts.com) quoted as saying “Iraqi officials now want a higher allocation within any OPEC production deal or else will seek exemption, claiming revenue is needed to battle Islamic State militants”  Oil demand expected to grow based on the assumption of rising vehicle sales in US, China and India, and demand for petrochemical feedstocks There are also global political issues to focus on within the next month that could have big impacts of the price of crude oil: USA Presidential elections, increasing political tensions between Russia and the West, fight against ISIS, impacts from Brexit… Crude prices rose in August partly due to the weakness of the US dollar. However, US Feds have said it is possible that interest rates will increase in December which will bring down the price/barrel of oil 
The December-loading Oman futures contract settled at $50.23/b (breaking the $50 mark for the first time in 12 months). Given the price rise that occurred when OPEC announced it would make a deal to freeze production, it is possible that the oil price will increase after their meeting, however given the number of political issues that will affect oil prices right now it seems the price for November will be just marginally above $50 or marginally below $50.

Oil prices fell 1 percent on Tuesday, with U.S. crude breaking below $50 per barrel for a second straight day ahead of weekly data that could show a build in domestic inventories. Analysts said verbal jockeying among the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) created uncertainty about potential output cuts at its meeting next month, noting that a particular worry was Iraq's exclusion from the plan. International Brent crude oil futures fell 89 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $50.57 per barrel by 2:40 p.m. ET (1840 GMT). U.S. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures settled down 56 cents, or 1.1 percent, to $49.96 a barrel.

Let's see:
1.The forward expectation of the future price (futures contracts) is already close to the $50 barrier on high volume.  
2.Saudi Arabia and Russia are the two largest crude oil producers holding more than a quarter of the world's production. An important point would be whether to expect a freeze or an outright cut, with the latter being already suggested by Putin.
3. Saudi and the US have grown apart during Obama, but we need to take into account its solid ties to Clinton given by the generous donations of the Saudi Royal Family to the Clinton Foundation. This makes a Clinton win more favorable towards lower prices on one hand, on the other rhetoric b/n Moscow and Washington/EU has been so aggressive that Putin my just decide to "stick it" to the West.

There is supposed to be an agreement between Saudi Arabia and Russia to limit output, but often these agreements break down because some countries negate them by increasing output. It also depends on demand. If oil currently in storage is released onto the market supply could be increased. A warm or mild autumn could change demand. It looks like $50 is the new mid point around which prices will drift around.
Russia to join OPEC in supply restrictions. Likely more restrictions announced during the OPEC meeting of Nov 30.

QUESTION:
- Should the forecast be adjusted to reflect OPEC's agreement to limit production?
-
-
BOTTOM LINE:
- No
-
-
NEWS:
- OPEC agreed to limit production to 32.5-33.0m b/d on 28 Sep (http://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/press_room/3706.htm)
- OPEC produced 33.5m b/d, according to the IEA Sep OMR (https://www.iea.org/oilmarketreport/reports/2016/0916/)
- Therefore, the implementation of the agreement would reduce global supply by 0.5-1.0m b/d
-
-
SHOULD THE FORECAST BE ADJUSTED TO REFLECT THE NEWS?
- YES:
-- Oil prices have risen from $46 to $51. Markets seem to believe OPEC. 
-
- NO:
-- Not ratified yet. Ratification will be on 30 Nov, which means implementation could be delayed into 2017. 
-
-- Agreeing on details and individual country quotas could be hard to achieve:
1-- Iraq is disputing the numbers. Says its production is 300k b/d higher than reported. This means the others have to cut by even more to maintain the limit. (http://www.wsj.com/articles/iraq-quarrel-on-production-number-could-sink-opec-deal-1475168419)
2-- Iran is reported to want to increase its production to 4.0m b/d from 3.65m b/d currently. 
3-- Both Libya and Nigeria have suffered from disruptions lately. Restoring their output to 2015 levels would add 0.1 and 0.3m b/d respectively. (IEA OMR Sep 2016)
-
--- If Iran, Iraq, Libya and Nigeria get exempted, the others would have to cut by 1.5-2.0m b/d to remain within the target limit. Difficult to see that happening. 
-
-
CONCLUSION:
- Leave forecast unchanged for now until an agreement is finalised and details have been agreed on.

Currently the price is over $48.5. A 10% to 20% change is quite possible in 8 weeks. It seems unlikely that events in Mosul (e.g. an attempt to retake it) would affect matters that much. Action or inaction from OPEC could affect it, but the next OPEC meeting is on 30th November. Its possible that OPEC members will try to talk up the possibility of restricting supply as the date for the meeting gets closer, but if its just talk and at the same time producers try and hedge to lock higher prices into their January deliveries they may not move prices up (as has been happening in the last couple of weeks).

Given oil volatility its quite difficult to exclude the extreme outcomes. I expect oil to drift up slowly with a fair value around 50 - 55, but conviction can't be high given the unpredictable nature of the asset

Futures prices have increased closer to the $50 mark in expectation of some OPEC actions to try and reduce supply, but as price rises so shale producers increase production so it seems the price will stick between $40 and $50 (unless some event occurs)

Potential oil production limitation agreement by OPEC?

BOTTOM LINE:
- P(<40) = 10%; P(between 40 & 50) = 56%; P(between 50 & 60) = 32%; P(>60) = 2%
-
-
OUTSIDE VIEW:
- Assume that the annual returns of the Jan-17 contract follows a normal distribution with mean zero and standard deviation of 30%
- I calculate the probability that it would fall in each of the hypothesised values using this distribution
-
-
INSIDE VIEW:
- Assume no shale response. If the price rises above $60, US shale will not make a comeback. Why not? Shale would probably not respond this quickly.
-
- Assume the value of the contract is not impacted by supply and demand factors. Why not? Fundamentals probably do not matter over a short forecasting horizon.
-
-
FORECAST UPDATE PROCEDURE:
- Update on a daily basis using the assumed distribution in the outside view and the most up-to-date value of the Jan-17 contract

I'm seeing a Target price around $48, but I think there is a lot more volatility than everyone else. I could see the price going up or down $10 in any given month. The daily change is typically over $1 alone.  Also, there are rumors that OPEC just slashed production and oil prices are up 5%.

OPEC agreement could support short lived rally upon the illusion supply concerns will overdone. But in the long run this scenario brings back to  life shale producers. Today (at current prices) each week more US / Canada rigs are back into production.

I once heard a leading oil analyst laugh out loud when a bbc business journalist asked what he thought the price of oil would be in 6 months (laughing because of how it is simply impossible to predict that far in the future with any real certainty in his opinion). This forecast obviously has a shorter time frame, but the point holds even if diluted somewhat. I've worked as a scientist on a lot of oil and gas projects, but not as a petroleum futures expert.  I do know that USA drillers have been so innovative at reducing costs in the last several years that they can mostly produce profitably at around $50/ barrel and much lower in any cases. And there is so much oil available in the USA and production capacity/ security is so ensured with the right prices that I don't see how even a doubtful output limit agreement between Russia and OPEC could boost prices much above $50/ barrel in the next 2 months. Having said all that, an unexpected polar vortex for instance could put Europe into an early winter onset accompanied by a forecast for it to continue through the winter, thereby blowing any $50/ barrel prediction out of the water. Likewise there are security and war concerns, and we are talking about Dubai contracts. I really enjoy predicting oil questions because of the subject, but the more I learn about oil and the various factors affecting its price, the more I start to understand why the expert laughed when asked to predict the oil price 6 months out.

The graph for the Jan17 futures contract shows a range of $40-$50 over the last four months, spare one day above $50 and about a week below $40. Sep16 and Nov16 futures contracts show a similar range, albeit shifted about $1 lower.  While this would demonstrate a slight expectation for long term increases in the Dubai/Oman crude oil price, I don't believe it is enough of a jump over a relatively short period to warrant a more likely forecast above $50. Slight buffer included for supply shocks on the downside or some shock to the system, such as an attack in the region, which could cause a spike in prices.
